Award.AwardTitle: US-Brazil Planning Visit: An Integrated Approach to Resolving the late Paleozoic Ice Age in the Parana Basin, Brazil
Award.AbstractNarration:
US-Brazil Planning Visit: A Collaborative Effort to Reconstruct the Climate of the Last Icehouse in the Paraná Basin, Brazil

Part1:
This international collaborative research will revolutionize our ability to correlate geologic, paleoclimate, and biotic events throughout South America and will permit assessment of the degree of global synchroneity of events and the nature of teleconnections in the late Paleozoic climate system. The geochronologic framework we will develop has the potential to also contribute to unraveling the tectonic evolution of the Andes and shedding light on the origin of economic metals and petroleum resources in South America. The long-term international collaboration will facilitate the exchange of scientific and education information and resources by the investigators and provide more diverse training of US and Brazilian undergraduate and graduate students.

Part2:
The last icehouse on Earth (340 to 260 million years ago), prior to our current glacial world, was the longest lived and most geographically extensive ice age of the past half billion years. Despite substantially different geography than today, the late Paleozoic Ice Age (LPIA) provides insight into the response of icehouse climate processes and the biosphere to major perturbation, including CO2-forcing of climate. The demise of this icehouse records the only transition of a vegetated and metazoan world from a glacial state to fully greenhouse conditions. Studies of the past two decades have raised fundamental questions and defined paradoxes regarding the climate system and climate-life linkages during this time. Resolving these scientific issues requires better time constraints for high-latitude depositional basins that contain a rich record of the LPIA. The Paraná Basin is an ideal natural laboratory as it contains one of the thickest successions of late Paleozoic glacial and post-glacial strata and has long been considered a key geographic piece of the puzzle regarding the nature and timing of glaciation in Gondwana. Widely distributed volcanic ashes offer the potential to develop a U-Pb dated higher latitude record of high temporal resolution and continuity. Sedimentary deposits, which are rich in paleoclimate proxies and characterize the successions above and between glacial deposits provide an opportunity to evaluate, via fossil soil, geochemical and fossil leaf analyses, how the regional climate conditions and paleo-atmospheric CO2 varied between glacial maxima and glacial minima.

We are carrying out a planning visit and reconnaissance fieldtrip to initiate an international research and education collaboration with Brazilian investigators at the Universidade Federal do Rio Grande Do Sul (Roberto Iannuzzi) and the Universidade Federal do Paraná (Fernando Farias Vesely). The longer-term collaborative project, which integrates the group?s complimentary scientific interests and expertise, focuses on three research objectives that will improve our understanding of the climate system and climate-life linkages during this last icehouse. These include (1) developing high-precision U-Pb ages for ashes within the Permo-Carboniferous succession of the Paraná Basin, (2) integrating field evidence of the geographic distribution of ice sheets with the U-Pb and Hf isotopic compositions of detrital zircons from glacial deposits in order to reconstruct the ice sheet history in west-central Gondwana, and (3) developing high-resolution climate records for the Paraná Basin & assess their linkages to the glaciation history, Gondwanan paleobotanical records, and existing lower-latitude (paleotropical) proxy records.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative planning grant was designed to initiate a long term international research and educational collaboration focused on resolving the causes and extent of the late Paleozoic Ice Age (LPIA) by investigating Carboniferous and Permian strata in the Paraná Basin, Brazil. The LPIA represents an 80-110 Ma interval of glaciation followed by Earth’s last complete transition to greenhouse conditions. Early views portrayed the ice age as represented by a single, long-duration event where a massive ice sheet covered much of Gondwana. However, recent work now reveals that glaciation was characterized by numerous, smaller, ice sheets that waxed and waned diachronously across the supercontinent with glacial events lasting millions of years alternating with non-glacial intervals of equal duration. Continued study of this important time is allowing for a deeper understanding of the timing, size, duration, and dynamics of this ice age, and thus, it provides for a deeper appreciation of icehouse to greenhouse transitions and teleconnections with other Earth systems. 

The Paraná Basin is an ideal natural laboratory for study of the LPIA as it contains one of the thickest successions of late Paleozoic glacial and post-glacial strata in Gondwana and it has long been considered a key geographic piece of the puzzle regarding the nature and timing of glaciation given its climatically sensitive temperate location and proximity to multiple paleo-topographic centers. Determining the extent and timing of glaciation are key to understanding how glaciation impacted Earth’s Carboniferous and Permian physical, chemical, and biologic systems. The abundance of easily accessible outcrops and quarries scattered around Brazil, and an abundance of rock cores originally taken for mineral and fossil fuel exploration provided the opportunity to establish an extensive data base for conducting our long term studies. Widely distributed volcanic ashes offer the potential to develop a U-Pb calibrated, higher latitude record of high temporal resolution and continuity. Sedimentary deposits, which are rich in paleoclimate proxies and characterize the successions above and between glacial deposits provide an untapped opportunity to quantitatively evaluate how the regional climate conditions and paleo-atmospheric CO2 varied between glacial and non-glacial times. Our Brazilian collaborators bring unique field (Vesely, Universidade Federal do Paraná) and paleobotanical (Iannuzzi, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul) expertise in the geologic and ecologic history of the Paraná Basin, while the US collaborators bring expertise in state-of-the-art U-Pb dating (Mundil, Berkeley Geochronology Center), quantitative reconstruction of past climates and paleo-atmospheric CO2 (Montañez, University of California-Davis), and glacial sedimentology and ice sheet reconstruction (Isbell, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee).

 Collaboration on this grant has created the framework for the longer duration project by establishing proof of concept by developing:

1. a high-precision U-Pb calibrated chronostratigraphic framework for the Permo-Carboniferous succession in the southern portion of the Paraná Basin, into which other components of the proposed research will be integrated;

2. constraining the timing, geographic extent, and volume of paleo-ice sheets draining the Rio Grande do Sul shield in the south of the basin; and

3. initiating development of a high-resolution, temporally continuous, U-Pb calibrated climate records for the Paraná Basin & assess their linkages to the glaciation history, Gondwanan paleobotanical records, and existing lower-latitude (paleotropical) proxy records.

During August and September of 2015, PIs Isbell, Montañez, Mundil, and 2 Ph.D. students (Fedorchuk of UWM and Griffis of UCD), traveled to Brazil to meet with Brazilian colleagues, their students, and other scientists working on deposits of the LPIA. The group met with scientists and students from 5 universities which included Universidade Federal do Rio Grande Do Sul (UFRGS), Universidade Federal do Paraná (UFPR), Universidade do Contestado (UNC), Universidade do Extremo Sul Catarinense (UNESC), and Universidade do Vale do Rio dos Sinos (UNISINOS). The PIs gave colloqiums on the current state of problems associated with the LPIA, icehouse to greenhouse transitions, the problems that the group are addressing by examining strata in the Paraná Basin, and the techniques that we utilize in our long term studies. Iannuzzi and Vesely arranged for multiple field trips to examine the Paraná succession and to collect preliminary samples and data for the proof of concept portion of the study. In 2016, Isbell and three UWM students (fedorchuk, Pauls and Amato) returned to Brazil to continue the collaboration. Using a UWM grant, Isbell arranged for Vesely and a student to participate in a 10 day field trip to examine Pleistocene and Precambrian glacial features in Wisconsin and Ontario, Canada. The field component of the planning visit permitted us to test the potential for successfully carrying out longer-term research objectives, and the proof-of-concept results were used to develop a collaborative research proposal for the Sedimentary Geology and Paleobiology Program, Earth Sciences Division, Geosciences Directorate of NSF, which has now been funded.
